description: From Middle English tremour (“fright”), from Anglo-Norman tremour and Old French tremor, from Latin tremor.

entries.meaning: A rhythmic, uncontrollable shaking of all or part of the body due to partial muscle contractions.
examples: The optometrist has been losing patients ever since he developed tremors in his hand.
Did you feel the tremor this morning?

verbs.description: tremor (third-person singular simple present tremors, present participle tremoring, simple past and past participle tremored)

entries.meaning: To shake or quiver excessively and rapidly or involuntarily; to tremble.
examples: The ground tremored under their big boots.
